Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Participation in International Geoscience Unions: IUSS, INQUA, IUGS, and IUGG
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support the National Academies of Sciences (NAS), Board on International Scientific Organizations (BISO) to represent the relevant US science communities through separate National Committees (USNC) to four, individual International Geoscience Unions that are part of the International Science Council (ISC). These unions are the International Union of Soil Sciences (IUSS), the International Union for Quaternary Research (INQUA), the International Union of Geological Sciences (IUGS), and the International Union of Geodesy and Geophysics (IUGG). The main role of each U.S. National Committee (USNC) is to facilitate participation of American scientists in the activities of its respective union and to "advance US visibility and impact globally through the engagement, collaboration, and leadership of international scientific societies".

The USNC for Soil Science will work to advance U.S. soil science through topical symposia and national conferences and aid in the development of early career scientists through exposure to international soil science research at the World Congress of Soil Sciences. The USNC for Quaternary Research will play an important role in the scientific content of the 2019 International INQUA Congress and will organize topical sessions at U.S. professional society meetings on the future of and vision for Quaternary Research. The USNC for Geological Sciences will support the development of a more inclusive geologic workforce. The USNC for Geodesy and Geophysics will focus on nominating U.S. scientists for union leadership positions and will increase outreach to the geophysical and geodetical communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. National Committees (USNCs) for the International Union for Geodesy and Geophysics (IUGG),  the International Union for Geological Sciences (IUGS), International Union for Soil Science (IUSS), and the International Union for Quaternary Research (INQUA) are housed in the Board of International Scientific Organizations of the National Academy of Sciences. This award allowed the NAS and these four USNCs to represent the U.S. to their respective unions on governance and scientific issues, catalyze and facilitate the participation of the U.S. scientific community in these unions, organize activities to support U.S. geoscience, and support U.S. geoscience students and early career scientists.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The scientific unions initiate and promote international scientific programs, develop services and products, and foster international research cooperation. Thousands of international scientists and U.S. scientists from academia, Federal agencies, industry, and non-profits participate in their activities. The unions increasingly continue to promote the participation of scientists of all national origins and career stages. Under this award, U.S. delegations formally represented the U.S. at the Montreal IUGG and Dublin INQUA general assemblies. U.S. scientists hold positions of scientific and governance leadership, including INQUA and IUSS past presidents. U.S. scientists lead three out of five INQUA commissions and, in IUGS, serve as secretary general and councilor. In IUGG, U.S. scientists lead at both union and international association levels. Having U.S. scientists in leadership positions ensures that U.S. ideas, priorities, and values are represented and facilitates scientific interactions that benefit U.S. and world science alike. The USNCs support and lead efforts to increase diversity in union activities.

USNC members and staff have organized a short course, a workshop, and eight scientific sessions at meetings of organizations such as IUGG, INQUA, the Soil Science Society of America, the Geological Society of America (GSA), and the American Geophysical Union (AGU) on topics ranging from geoheritage to science diplomacy to the application of Quaternary research to societal problems. The USNC/IUGG was IUGG and AGU's principal partner in two day-long workshops: The AGU-IUGG Centennial Symposium on Disaster Science: Risk Reduction, Resilience, Response, and Recovery (2018 AGU Fall Meeting), and the AGU-IUGG Centennial Symposium Georisk Reduction: Science, Resources, and Governmental Action (2019 IUGG International Congress). USNC members and staff collaborate with other National Academies' Boards on activities such as the Dynamic Soil Information System workshop. USNC members and staff relay U.S. and international opportunities and information to U.S. geoscientists via direct communication, USNC websites, and social media.

BROADER IMPACT

Geoheritage is a particularly important application of geological science to challenging societal problems: how to protect our natural geological patrimony for current and future scientific, educational, and outreach use, while preserving the local communities' history and encouraging their sustainable development. The USNC/GS and its Advisory Group for Geoheritage and Geoparks organized a 2018 Town Hall and a 2-day short course and two oral sessions on geoheritage at the 2019 GSA Annual Meeting.  Geoheritage work involves academic and non-academic stakeholders and partnerships with organizations such as the Association of American State Geologists. The work of this committee has sparked the idea for the separately funded America's Geoheritage II Workshop: Identifying, Developing, and Preserving America's Natural Legacy.

USNC/Soils and staff collaborated in organizing the 2018 National Conference on Connections between Soil Health and Human Health led by the Soil Health Institute. This very well-regarded event, rooted in a 2016 USNC/Soils workshop, and attended by Federal and academic researchers and other stakeholders from a variety of disciplines encouraged long-overdue interactions between the soil health and human health communities.

The USNCs continue reaching out to the broad geoscience community to increase diversity in their ranks, in the speakers that volunteer for their activities, and in the applicants for its travel award programs. As a result, there is considerable improvement in career stage, gender, ethnicity, and geographic parameters.

The USNCs assist U.S. students and early career scientists by offering targeted workshops, such as Transcending Academic and National Boundaries and Advancing Scientific Discovery (2018 AGU Fall Meeting) and by organizing mentoring activities as part of travel award programs. USNC/INQUA organized a separately funded travel award program that helped 26 U.S. students and early career scientists defray the cost of attending the Dublin 20th INQUA International Congress to present their original research and expand their scientific networks. USNC/IUGS co-organized with GSA a separately funded travel award program for the 36th International Geological Congress, but the program was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To inform geoscience communities of our work and increase its visibility and reach, USNC members and staff have published articles on the USNC/INQUA travel award program and on the functions and recent activities of the USNC/Soils in professional society magazines.

The activities of the USNCs support the development of U.S. scientists at all career levels and highlight the role of basic geosciences for the benefit of humanity.
